docs.lead_paragraph: Jimmy Bosch is a trombonist who cha-chas with the biggest names in salsa, and his flaring melodies and frantic rhythms energize fans in 35 countries. But at H & H Bagels on West 46th Street, he is just Jim Bosch, the guy who calmly and matter-of-factly takes customer orders, packs bagels and checks inventory. Mr. Bosch, 38, started working there full time in 1992, when his music career stalled, and still comes in four or five afternoons a month.

headline.main: Salsa Trombone at Night, With Bagels by Day
headline.kicker: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE

docs.lead_paragraph: MARKETS Even With Yen Supported, Stocks Bounce About A bystander could be forgiven for thinking the stock markets had gone off their lithium. The Dow industrials skidded 207.01 points on Monday, to 8,627.93, only to soar 164.17 points on Wednesday and fall 100.14 on Friday. The blue-chip average ended the week at 8,712.87, down 122.07 from last week. Behind the stock market's zig was the currency market's zag. The fall reflected fears that Asia's economic crisis would hurt profits of American companies. Then the United States and Japan bought yen to bolster the sagging currency, and investors stampeded back into the markets, only to have second thoughts about the Asian situation on Friday. The yen, which had neared an eight-year low on Monday at 146.15 yen to the dollar, recovered to end the week at 136.10.

docs.lead_paragraph: In its rush to adjourn for the year, the State Legislature passed a bill that would overhaul school board elections in New York City, replacing paper ballots with voting machines and simplifying a system of weighted voting. Both steps would speed up the notoriously slow process of tallying results in school elections. But the Legislature did not follow a recommendation from government-reform groups to switch school board elections from May to November to coincide with the general election.

headline.main: Albany Passes A Bill to Speed School Voting

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-5 Colombia Agrees to Test Herbicide for Drug Control Colombia has agreed to a United States demand to test a chemical to kill coca crops, even though the manufacturer has warned against its use there. The Environmental Protection Agency says the chemical, tebuthiuron, can poison ground water, and Colombian officials fear it will spoil land where peasants could grow food. A1 Clinton Urged to Meet Dissident A group of 55 democracy advocates from China has called on President Clinton to meet with a prominent Beijing dissident during his visit to China next week. There was no immediate response from the White House, but diplomats said it was extremely unlikely that Mr. Clinton would do so. A3

docs.lead_paragraph: New York's State Legislature has done an excellent job of reducing expectations. When the lawmakers closed up shop and went home yesterday, relief that they had done so few things that were terrible overcame some of the disappointment over their failure to do much that was good. It was good news that the Legislature failed to pass a parole bill that was more election-year pandering than serious reform of the state's sometimes irrational sentencing system. In another accomplishment of sorts, the Assembly killed a boondoggle for mutual insurance companies sought by Gov. George Pataki and the Republican Senate.

docs.lead_paragraph: In an abrupt change of plans, Clinton Administration officials said today that they would restrict the initial distribution of a new consumer guide on the Medicare program because they feared that millions of elderly people would be utterly confused by its description of new health insurance options. Medicare officials had said as recently as June 4 that they intended to mail the new Medicare handbooks to all 38 million beneficiaries this fall, even though focus groups and surveys indicated that much of the complex information would be incomprehensible to readers.

headline.main: Medicare Officials to Limit Distribution of New Guide

docs.abstract: Clinton Administration officials decide to restrict initial distribution of new consumer guide on Medicare program after studies by Government and by American Assn of Retired Persons suggest many elderly people do not know differences between health maintenance organization and original fee-for-service Medicare program; without such information, they cannot intelligently assess new options, whose prices and benefits will be described in detail in new handbook; members of Congress from both parties had criticized handbook; Government will operate toll-free telephone number to answer questions about new insurance options in five states receiving handbooks; beneficiaries in other states will receive brief newsletter; they will not receive full handbook until next year (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Advice to mothers is as plentiful as air. There are hundreds of books and thousands of old wives' tales. On top of that is the daily unsolicited advice that mothers get from friends, relatives, even strangers on the street. What about advice to fathers? Tucked into books for mothers about what they should expect from their babies and children are usually a few pages telling them what they should expect from fathers (usually very little). There is also a growing shelf of books of advice for fathers: books encouraging them to take a greater part in the children's lives, books ordering them to take back their traditional roles and books jokingly telling them how to handle unpredictably moody wives and children.

headline.main: Father Knows Best, With Help: Kiss the Baby and Wife

docs.lead_paragraph: Some of the nation's biggest health insurers have decided not to pay for Viagra, the new male impotence drug, under their prescription drug plans. They said that providing the recommended 6 to 12 pills per month would be too expensive, adding hundreds of millions of dollars to annual costs. The drug has been promoted as an important enhancement to the quality of life for many older men and their wives, but some health economists have raised questions about the medical necessity of a treatment for impotence and the expense relative to other drugs.

headline.main: Many Insurers Are Deciding Not to Cover Cost of Viagra

docs.abstract: Some of nation's biggest health insurers have decided not to pay for Viagra, new male impotence drug, under their prescription drug plans; they say it would add hundreds of millions of dollars to annual costs to provide recommended 6 to 12 pills per month; drug has been promoted as important enhancement to quality of life for many older men and their wives, but some health economists question medical necessity of treatment for impotence and expense relative to other drugs; among insurance companies not covering Viagra are Kaiser Permanente and Aetna US Healthcare, as well as Medicaid in several states, including New York (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As the Legislature closed its 1998 session tonight, most major issues before it were left unresolved. Following is a review of the fate of the major bills that were considered on the final day.

headline.main: Most Major Issues Are Left Unresolved
